page.title: 12LANDSCAPE ASHBY M PEATLING P
page.content: The landscape in the area is undulating rising to a maximum height of 5OOft above MSL. The majority of the area is made up of small fields divided by hedgrows with small deciduous copses scattered about. These contain a mixture of traditional English native species except that the elm has almost disappeared due to Dutch Elm disease. Small brooks and streams drain the area and eventually flow into the Soar, Trent and Severn river systems. A significant portion of the area is occupied by the disused airfield built during the l939/45 war and presently used for warehousing and as a vehicle testing track. Villages have grown up around farms with a small number of l8th and l9th century houses/cottages and a growing number of modern properties.
